Further construction stalled due to environmental concerns, until President George W. Bush’s 2006 Secure Fence Act mandated that the Department of Homeland Security complete no fewer than 700 miles of fencing. In this photograph, repurposed railroad ties welded together mark a portion of the U.S.-Mexico border behind a giant saguaro #cactus spared from the building project in Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, a desert preserve in southern Arizona. Read more by @gengennygenevieve, and see more pictures, at the link in bio. Photograph by @elliotstudio

When photographer Elliot Ross (@elliotstudio) and Genevieve Allison (@gengennygenevieve) traveled the 2,000 miles of the U.S.-Mexico border, in the spring of 2017, the post-election climate had enflamed a sense of cultural and political difference in the United States—much of which centered around the debate about the border wall. The pair set out expecting to find residents there who were fundamentally vexed by the relationship between the U.S. and #Mexico; between immigrant, indigenous and Caucasian communities; and between border inhabitants and undocumented migrants. Instead, she writes, they found the opposite—and heard about fears largely left unvoiced. In this photograph, Jaymin Martinez stands in her #quinceañera dress next to the border fence in Brownsville, #Texas. Read more, and see more pictures, at the link in bio. Photograph by @elliotstudio

Mexico refused to pay for it. Congress wouldn’t shell out, either. So President Trump capped a two-month battle over his border wall by deciding to go it alone. “We’re going to be signing today, and registering, [a] national emergency,” #Trump said in a statement at the White House Rose Garden on Feb. 15. “And it’s a great thing to do, because we have an invasion of gangs, an invasion of drugs, and an invasion of people.” (Top government officials have disputed the President's characterization of threats at the border.) The unprecedented move allows Trump to signal to supporters that he’s still fighting to deliver the wall, while also sidestepping a second politically damaging shutdown. But the risky maneuver opens a Pandora’s box of future challenges, both in the courts and in Congress. And Republicans fear it raises the prospect of a future Democratic President wielding national emergencies as a tool to bypass Congress on liberal political priorities like climate change and gun restrictions. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

You don’t have to be a botany expert to figure out what it means when somebody sends you a rose. Every year on Feb. 14, millions of people exchange the flower to express their #love. An estimated 250 million roses were produced for #ValentinesDay in 2018, according to the Society of American Florists. And Kenya—where these photographs were made in recent days as workers picked and packaged roses at Wildfire Flowers in Naivasha, outside Nairobi—is one of the largest suppliers of cut #flowers to the European Union, according to the Kenya Flower Council. But the rose’s life as a symbol didn’t begin with romance. Read more about why we give roses on Valentine's Day—and what the #🌹 really means—at the link in bio. Photographs by @andrewrenneisen—@gettyimages

Tori Gonzalez, whose boyfriend Joaquin Oliver was among 17 people killed in the February 2018 mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in #Parkland, Fla., wears a medallion with a picture of 'Guac,' as he was known, during the opening of the 'Walls of Demand' exhibition in Washington, D.C., on Feb. 12. In the year since the shooting, teachers and students at Stoneman Douglas have formed their own support networks, leaning on each other through group texts, service projects and mindfulness exercises as they have tried to adjust to a new normal. “We have that shared experience. If someone is crying, we get it. If someone is yelling or angry, we understand," psychology teacher Ronit Reoven tells TIME. "We’re there to hug. We’re there to listen." She says she considered not returning because of her anxiety, but decided it was important to support her students and colleagues. Reoven and Gonzalez, a senior, built a garden memorial outside of the school. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Nicholas Kamm—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

@maria_ressa, founder of the news website @rappler, was arrested in the #Philippines on Feb. 13 on charges of “cyber libel” that are widely seen as a crackdown on the site’s reporting. The charges were filed over a 2012 story about businessman Wilfredo Keng and his alleged links to illegal drugs and human trafficking. The Cybercrime Prevention Act—a controversial law that prompted fears of censorship because it made online libel a crime punishable by up to 12 years in jail—was enacted months later. In an interview with TIME last week, Ressa, who appeared on one of TIME’s Person of the Year covers in December, said, “It is part of the same government effort to try to make Rappler toe the line, which is, ‘You shouldn’t be reporting on the drug war. You should be reporting how wonderful our country is today.’ It is just not what we do.” She added: “I want to face this—because the more ludicrous the cases are, the clearer it is that these are tools that are being used to try to silence us.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @moisessaman—@magnumphotos for TIME

Islamic State militants cornered in their last foothold in eastern #Syria fought back with suicide car bombs, snipers and booby traps this week, slowing an advance by Kurdish fighters under the cover of U.S.-led coalition airstrikes according to Kurdish news agencies and a Syrian war monitor, @apnews reports. It's unclear how many ISIS fighters are still holding out and whether civilians remain inside. Some 20,000 people have fled fighting in the past few weeks, overwhelming camps in the northeast, the Associated Press adds. In this photograph on Feb. 12, civilians arrive after an hours-long walk to a Syrian Democratic Forces position on the outskirts of Baghouz, the last village held by the extremists. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @cmcgrath_photo—@gettyimages

More than 3,000 #dogs from 204 breeds competed in this year's #Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York City. 2019’s season introduced two new breeds to the competition—the Nederlandse Kooikerhondje and the Grand Basset Griffon Vendéen, in the sporting and hound groups, respectively. It also brought back all the anticipated fun and barking—and hair, as shown in these images on Feb. 12. In the third photograph is a Bouviers des Flandres, followed by a Lakeland Terrier. See more pictures at the link in bio. Photographs by @claramokriphoto for TIME

Notorious kingpin Joaquín “El Chapo” Guzmán was found guilty on Feb. 12 of all charges stemming from his role in trafficking billions of dollars worth of drugs into the U.S. as a top boss within the Sinaloa cartel. In the sixth day of deliberations, a jury convicted the 61-year-old drug lord, who has been standing trial in federal court in Brooklyn since mid-November. Guzmán, who infamously escaped from two top security prisons in #Mexico, now faces life behind bars in America. In this photograph from February 2018, while TIME was reporting in Guzmán’s hometown of La Tuna, José, who calls Guzmán an uncle, hosts a barbecue with family and friends near Guzmán’s mother’s compound. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @kirstenluce for TIME

North Korea and South Korea are expected to inform the International Olympic Committee of their ambitions to co-host the 2032 Olympics during a meeting in Switzerland on Feb. 15. South Korea chose Seoul for the planned bid on Feb. 11; #NorthKorea has not yet announced its desired host city, though Pyongyang is expected. U.S.-led sanctions against the North would present significant challenges to hosting an Olympics in the country. Feasibility is dependent on the North's denuclearization plans, which will be discussed during the upcoming summit between Kim Jong Un and U.S. President Donald Trump in Vietnam. #Sports diplomacy is not new in the region: in 2018, the North sent athletes and a delegation (including Kim's sister) to the Winter Olympics held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. In this photograph on Feb. 5, a woman pulls a child in a sled at Masikryong Ski Resort near Wonsan, North Korea. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @carl_court—@gettyimages

When viewers of the #Grammys called out the lack of awards for #women last year, Neil Portnow, the outgoing Recording Academy president and CEO, replied: “I think [change] has to begin with women who have the creativity in their hearts and souls, who want to be #musicians, who want to be engineers, who want to be producers, who want to be part of the industry on the executive level to step up.” (“I guess this year we really stepped up,” Best New Artist @dualipa quipped during the 61st Annual Grammy Awards telecast on Feb. 10, just before an abrupt cut to commercial.) In 2019, writes TIME television critic Judy Berman, the Grammys finally felt the wrath of all the superstars the Academy had alienated over the years. The award for Best Rap Album? It went to Cardi B, who became the first solo female artist to win in the category. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Lester Cohen—@gettyimages for The Recording Academy

If current trends continue, China’s population will peak at 1.44 billion in 2029 before entering “unstoppable” decline, according to a recent study. By 2050, 330 million Chinese will be over the age of 65. China, whose extraordinary economic heft has been built on labor-intensive manufacturing, is uniquely ill-prepared for the societal changes that this gray wave will bring. Fewer people means less domestic consumption, and thus rapidly slowing economic growth. The scale of the aging problem in China is partly due to the legacy of the one-child policy. Although the Chinese government now discourages women from delaying marriage for their careers, many women continue to prioritize their professional life over starting a family. Ma Ying (pictured) says she and her husband would prefer to raise their daughter, Sang Tianyi, 3, as an only child. Read more at the link in the bio. Photograph by @chiyin_sim—@magnumphotos for TIME

A little more than three years ago, Marlon James made a comment he now insists was a joke. The acclaimed Jamaican author told a reporter that his next project would be an “African Game of Thrones.” James underestimated the buzz the comparison would stir up, and soon enough, multiple outlets published breathless stories about the diverse epic fantasy he had promised. He even received an email from George R.R. Martin. James’ book, "Black Leopard, Red Wolf," which hit shelves on Feb. 5, is set in a distant-past Africa and filled with queer characters of color inspired by the continent’s history and mythology. It joins the ranks of those by authors like Tomi Adeyemi and N.K. Jemisin, whose works push back against stereotypes about the types of figures who “should” appear in fantasy fiction. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Ike Edeani (@edeani) for TIME

Yanze Bulama, 35, was hemorrhaging badly after she delivered a stillborn baby at home at 37 weeks pregnant. The Nigerian Borno state—which is at the epicenter of a decade–long Islamist insurgency led by Boko Haram—is one of the worst places in the world to give birth. More than 6,500 newborns die every year of preventable causes—twice the rate of the rest of the country, and between 3,500 and 4,500 women die every year due to childbirth-related causes. Nigeria, with UNICEF’s help, has deployed midwives to work in the health clinics of Borno state’s internally displaced camps. But around 80% of women in the Borno state of Nigeria still deliver at home. Many depend on the help of traditional birth attendants who, though well-meaning, can make complications in delivery worse. Rather than compete with traditional attendants, UNICEF has started offering them training jobs in the camp clinics. Read more at the link in the bio. Photograph by @lynseyaddario for TIME

Kellu Dauda is a midwife at a UNICEF-supported clinic in Ngala, in Borno state, Nigeria. Since September 2017, 50 midwives have been deployed to the Borno state to manage health clinics set up in the internally displaced. The drive to get women out of their home and into the clinic is already beginning to bear fruit in the region—the Banki clinic has yet to see a case of maternal mortality in the 1,271 babies delivered since 2018. “Delivery at home is a serious problem here,” says Dauda. “When you deliver in the clinic, we can take care of problems. If there is a tear, we have sutures. If you are bleeding, we can help. When you deliver at home, anything can go wrong.” Read more at the link in the bio. Photograph by @lynseyaddario for TIME

Alima Modu Babayo holds her baby for the first time, seconds after giving birth in the State Specialist Hospital in Maiduguri, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The Nigerian Borno state—which is at the epicenter of a decade–long Islamist insurgency led by Boko Haram—is one of the worst places in the world to give birth. More than 6,500 newborns die every year of preventable causes—twice the rate of the rest of the country, and between 3,500 and 4,500 women die every year due to childbirth-related causes. Nigeria is trying to change the narrative in the northeast, with @unicef‘s help, by deploying midwives to work in the health clinics of Borno state’s internally displaced camps. The Banki clinic didn’t see a single case of maternal mortality in the 1,271 babies delivered in 2018. Read more at the link in the bio. Photograph by @lynseyaddario for TIME

Dragon dancers perform at a park in Beijing on the fourth day of the #LunarNewYear on Feb. 8. China is marking the arrival of the Year of the Pig, which began on Feb. 5, with a week-long #SpringFestival holiday, the most important festival of the year. Read more about the #ChineseNewYear at the link in bio. Photograph by Greg Baker—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Acting Attorney General Matt Whitaker's testimony this Friday before the House Judiciary Committee was the first time an official from President Trump's administration has come before the newly empowered House Democrats in a public setting, and the tensions were on full display. Whitaker resisted questioning, at one point cutting off the chairman to note "I see that your 5 minutes is up," drawing gasps from the hearing room. Whitaker testified that he had not spoken with Trump about Mueller and denied interfering with the investigation. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

“I don’t ever stop painting in my mind. When I am in bed, unable to sleep, I see paint moving across the ceiling and imagine it spilling and pouring as it flows through the nooks and cracks,” says @frankbowlingra, who was born in Guyana, studied at London's Royal College of Art and began his career as an #artist amid the British Pop Movement of the 1950s and '60s. Bowling, who is known for abstract compositions in which he pours paint onto canvas, became the first black British artist elected to England’s Royal Academy of Art in 2005. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @djenebaaduayom for TIME

"Optimism is a cheerful obligation," says Jenny Holzer, a conceptual #artist known for her text-based art which address themes of power, politics and social injustice. Her work often uses simple but potent statements like ‘ABUSE OF POWER COMES AS NO SURPRISE’ and is regularly seen in both museums and public spaces like Times Square. “I am pretty convinced the sky is falling all the time, so I think it’s worthwhile to point to that and occasionally offer a solution,” she tells TIME. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @djenebaaduayom for TIME

“When I listen to music I am inspired by, I tend to daydream about the movement, to almost see it in a calligraphic way," @jeffreycirio, the lead principal dancer of the English National Ballet, tells TIME. In 2015, Cirio co-founded a collaborative #dance collective with his sister Lia. Their goal was to create a space for dancers and choreographers to create work without the constraints of traditional conservatories. “Dance is very freeing. On a stage or in a studio I am able to give that freedom to others.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @djenebaaduayom for TIME

"Teenagers bring so much truthfulness and rawness to art because we’re angry, we’re sad, we’re in love and we’re not afraid to make that heard,” Kinsale Hueston (@kinsalehues), a 2017 National Student Poet, tells TIME. "My poetry empowers my activism,” says the writer and college student, who is a member of Navajo Nation. Her award-winning work focuses on Native culture. "My poetry is a way for me to become more visible and, by doing so, create room for people who share my identity. It gives me a voice and a platform.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @djenebaaduayom for TIME

“When I look at the history and the brilliance of African Americans, it gives me a tremendous amount of optimism with perspective,” writes @lavernecox, an actor, activist and producer, and the first openly transgender person to receive an Emmy nomination for acting, for TIME. “It is horrible what far too many of us have endured. But the history of black excellence in America gives us a template for how to fight—and how to not be demoralized by the fight.” She points to singers Leontyne Price (pictured) and Marian Anderson as examples of those who “dared to create a space for themselves that did not exist before.” Read her full essay at the link in bio. Photograph by @gettyimages

Life is full of beautiful little ­moments, if you take the time to look. And looking is ­photographer Clay Benskin’s specialty. Wandering New York City with camera in hand, he captures scenes that would otherwise disappear. “I just enjoy people,” the 48-year-old tells TIME. “Everything fascinates me.” His efforts to capture an ever changing city—without any formal training—are a reminder that #photography is perhaps the ultimate democratic art form. Read more about Benskin's photography, and see more of his images, at the link in bio. Photographs by @clay_benskin for TIME

”Optimism is radical. It is the hard choice, the brave choice," Oscar-winning filmmaker Guillermo Del Toro writes in TIME's Optimists issue, guest edited by @ava. "Every day, we all become the balance of our choices—choices between love and fear, belief or despair. No hope is ever too small. Optimism is our instinct to inhale while suffocating." Read Del Toro's full essay at the link in bio. Photo-illustration by KangHee Kim (@tinycactus)

When TIME approached photographer Aida Muluneh to create images for our new Optimists issue, guest-edited by @ava, she turned to #Ethiopia’s political climate for inspiration. A new Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed, had assumed office in April 2018 and started implementing a series of reforms. “He instilled a different energy that was needed in our country,” Muluneh tells TIME. “There were a lot of changes that incited optimism for many of us.” Among those changes was a renewed championing of the role of #women in politics. As she began sketching out ideas relating to political #optimism, she was keen to include female models and emphasize their role in #politics and society. “Part of my optimism is about celebrating African cultures and traditions, but also about the need for the female voice.” Describing how the flower might represent love, friendship and understanding, Muluneh points out that her work is open to interpretation. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @aidamuluneh for TIME

How does an #artist keep her ­creative vision alive? It’s a concern not just for painters and poets who have been at work for decades; an artist’s vision can be tested at any point in life. For the nine people photographed in the Artists at Every Age portfolio—­from 18-year-old poet @kinsalehues to 94-year-old actor #CicelyTyson—what keeps them at work is the possibility of connecting with others. Photographer Djeneba Aduayom wanted to capture the essence of each artist and their relationship to art. “It was about looking through the lens and seeing who they were,” Aduayom tells TIME. Cicely Tyson, the celebrated actor who appears on one of two covers for this week's Optimists issue, speaks to TIME about her storied career, optimism and how her #art has affected others. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @djenebaaduayom for TIME

However the next few weeks and months unravel, Venezuelans have a long road to restore their country and way of life. The country’s natural resources have been ransacked, its industries crippled and its institutions corroded, says Alejandro Rebolledo, a Venezuelan lawyer. (He was forced into exile in Miami when parliament tried to appoint him to the supreme court in 2017 and the government threatened to arrest him.) “We don’t only need a change of government. We need to rebuild our state.” But before they can look to the future, Venezuelans are looking to opposition leader @jguaido. As he spends his days weaving through #Caracas, rushing from protest to parliament session to strategy meeting, and dodging the latent threat of arrest, he seems unfazed. “There’s certainty that we are going to change things,” he tells @time. “That energy is a very powerful motor.” In these photographs: tear gas floats over the pavement during a #protest on Jan. 23; a crowd gathers to listen to Guaidó during a news conference on Jan. 25; a woman fixes a flag on her chest during the news conference; and a man ties a piece of fabric to cover his face during a protest on Jan. 23. Read more at the link in bio. Photographs by @andrernandez

Two men claim to be the President of #Venezuela, which has the largest oil reserves on the planet and so little food that, in a single year, the average citizen lost 24 pounds. One, Nicolás Maduro, secured a second term in a 2018 election widely regarded as a sham. The other, @jguaido, took an oath of office on Jan. 23, in a maneuver that was equal parts audacious and ingenious, and that offered the nation at least the possibility of a peaceful way out of its catastrophe. The trick was finding a possible opening in the mire of Maduro’s authoritarianism. By fiat and force, #Maduro has spent the last few years remaking the #Caracas government to his liking—replacing justices on the Supreme Court, declaring emergency rule, and sidelining the parliament that the opposition had won in a free and fair ballot in 2015. Maduro also created from whole cloth the electoral apparatus that allowed him to remain in office without facing an opponent—a violation of the country’s 1999 constitution. In response, the leader of parliament—Guaidó, photographed by @andrernandez on Feb. 5—said the presidential office had essentially been left vacant in January, the start of Maduro’s rigged second term. He then invoked the constitution’s Article 233, which, in a power vacuum, calls for the person in his role to temporarily assume the presidency. In the days that followed, most Latin American countries, the U.S. and much of Western Europe recognized #Guaidó as the legitimate leader of the most troubled country in the hemisphere, and mounted intense economic and diplomatic pressure on Maduro to step down. In Caracas, massive public demonstrations gathered to support the 35-year-old. By uniting a divided opposition, Guaidó appears to have given Venezuela its first real chance to restore democracy since its socialist experiment collapsed into economic chaos in 2014. “The difference now is there’s absolute hope,” he told TIME a week after the ceremony, his voice hoarse from days of campaigning. “Despair, disillusionment and frustration, have become energy, strength, a determination to fight.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @andrernandez for TIME

In the very moment he started to speak, President Trump split his State of the Union address in two. Before giving the annual address to Congress, the president is traditionally introduced by the Speaker, whose chamber he’s visiting. It’s a nicety, a nod to the separation of powers being ceremonially set aside for the speech. But either accidentally or intentionally, Trump began his speech before @speakerpelosi could introduce him. An otherwise by-the-book opening with tips to “Madam Speaker, Mr. Vice President” and his fellow #Americans was marred by a slight against his archrival. It was symbolic of the entire #SOTU, which veered so wildly between soaring calls for unity and pitched partisan jabs that he may as well have given two different speeches. Read @time's full analysis by Brian Bennett, who covers the White House, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

Grace Eline, a young cancer #survivor, stands next to First Lady Melania Trump after President Trump mentioned her as a White House guest during his State of the Union address in Washington, D.C., on Feb. 5. Every president since Ronald Reagan has kept up with the tradition of inviting a citizen whose life and actions fall in line with the themes of the speech and mentioning them during the address. At 9 years old, according to the White House, Grace was diagnosed with Germinoma, a germ-cell brain tumor; she started #cancer treatment last May. "Throughout the rest of the year, Grace stayed positive and strong, making the rounds in the hospital, cheering up other patients, and always having a smile for the many caring medical professionals who treated her," the White House noted. "Grace recently finished chemotherapy and today shows no evidence of the disease. She is determined to help other #children who are fighting cancer." Read more about the #SOTU guests at the link in bio. Photograph by @polarisimages

After he applauded at his own State of the Union address in 2018, Donald Trump went viral. This year, it was @speakerpelosi who got all the applause online. For those watching #SOTU at home, the moment was so brief you might have missed it. But @nytimes photographer Doug Mills didn't: @nytmills captured an image of #Trump appearing to turn back to face #Pelosi as she clapped with outstretched arms. Some Trump critics came to the immediate conclusion that she was trolling the president. As always, in the grand tradition of photographs that become #memes, people see what they want to see. Read more, and see a selection of the memes, at the link in bio. Photograph by Doug Mills (@nytmills)—@nytimes/Pool/@reuters

As a candidate and as president, Donald Trump has had a number of opportunities to reset, moderate his rhetoric or find a compromise with his opponents: when he locked up the #Republican nomination, squared off against @hillaryclinton in debates, took the oath of office and hired John Kelly as chief of staff, to name a few. Each time, the pivot has been brief or nonexistent, and #Trump has returned to old habits shortly. Before his State of the Union address on Feb. 5, the White House gave hints that he would follow the script set by his predecessors, avoiding divisive rhetoric and stressing common goals like improving infrastructure and lowering prescription drug prices. A brief preview of the speech last week included lines about “bridging old divisions,” healing “old wounds” and building “new coalitions.” Trump said he’ll call for “unity.” Then again, this is Trump, who mused that Democrats who didn’t clap at his last #SOTU address were “treasonous” and has often defined unity as his opponents coming around to his point of view. Trump could reset his presidency during this address. Read why he may not at the link in bio. Photograph by Doug Mills (@nytmills)—@nytimes/Pool/@reuters

Democratic #women are wearing white clothing to make a coordinated #fashion statement around President #Trump's State of the Union address in Washington, D.C., on Feb. 5. Borrowing from the color used by the early 20th century movement to recognize women’s right to vote, the House Democratic Women’s Working Group invited lawmakers to wear white as a sign of #solidarity. In this photograph, @speakerpelosi stands with Democratic House members during a photo-op that recognized suffragettes. Last year, the group asked both male and female members of Congress to wear black to the #SOTU to show solidarity with the #MeToo and Time’s Up movements. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Joshua Roberts (@jprpix)—@reuters

A worker raises #China's national flag outside the Beijing Railway Station on Feb. 3. Millions of people have started traveling home to visit their families during the Spring Festival holiday period that begins with the #LunarNewYear on Feb. 5. Photograph by @kevinfrayer—@gettyimages

The New England @patriots defeated the Los Angeles @rams 13-3 in Super Bowl 53 in #Atlanta on Feb. 3, giving New England its sixth #SuperBowl title; only the Pittsburgh @steelers share that total. Pats rookie running back Sony Michel (@flyguy2stackz) scored on a two-yard touchdown run to give the Pats a 10-3 lead with 7 minutes left in the game. On that drive, we got a glimpse of vintage @tombrady: He connected with two of his most trusted hands, Rob Gronkowski and Julian Edelman, on long completions to set up the game-deciding touchdown. (He threw two completions to @gronk. @edelman11, who finished with 10 catches for 141 yards, won Super Bowl MVP. In this photograph, he's embracing Brady.) For #football purists who appreciate defensive tactics, big hits and three yards and a cloud of dust offense, #SuperBowl53 was a treat. But for the rest of us, writes @time's Sean Gregory, not so much. Even CBS analyst @tony.romo, known for accurate play predictions and his Mr. Sunshine demeanor in the booth, said at one point “this is hard to watch.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Morry Gash (@morryg)—@apnews #🏈

Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam, flanked by his wife Pam, speaks with reporters in Richmond on Feb. 2. Northam has faced a flood of calls to resign after a racist picture surfaced from his 1984 medical yearbook that shows a person in blackface and another wearing a Ku Klux Klan hood. @governorralphnortham issued an apology on Friday when the picture became public, saying in a statement he was “sorry for the decision I made to appear as I did in this photo.” The next day, he changed course and said "I am not either of the people in this photo." Northam did, however, admit to “darkening his face” in a Michael Jackson dance contest in Texas around the same time. @speakerpelosi called the photo “racist and contrary to fundamental American values” and called for him to “do the right thing.” Should Northam leave office, Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax, a Democrat and the second African-American to win statewide office in #Virginia, would become governor, the Associated Press reports. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @alexedelmanphotography—@gettyimages

At a congressional hearing on national security threats, leaders of all the major intelligence agencies—including the Directors of National Intelligence, the CIA and the FBI, photographed on Jan. 29—contradicted President Trump on issues relating to North Korea, Russia, the Islamic State and Iran. In response, Trump said the intelligence chiefs were "passive and naïve" and suggested they "should go back to school." In the wake of his renewed attacks on the U.S. intelligence community, senior intelligence briefers are breaking two years of silence to warn that the President is endangering American security with what they say is a stubborn disregard for their assessments. Citing multiple in-person episodes, these officials say Trump displays what one called "willful ignorance" when presented with analyses generated by #America’s $81 billion-a-year intelligence services. The officials, who include analysts who prepare Trump’s briefs and the briefers themselves, describe futile attempts to keep his attention by using visual aids, confining some briefing points to two or three sentences, and repeating his name and title as frequently as possible. What is most troubling, say these officials and others in government and on Capitol Hill who have been briefed on the episodes, are Trump’s angry reactions when he is given information that contradicts positions he has taken or beliefs he holds. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Martin H. Simon—picture-alliance/dpa/@apnews

@lindseyvonn, the first American woman to win an Olympic gold medal in downhill #skiing, is retiring. Vonn, 34, announced the news in an @instagram post on Feb. 1, saying her two upcoming races at the World Championships in Åre, Sweden, will be the last of her career. "My body is broken beyond repair and it isn't letting me have the final season I dreamed of. My body is screaming at me to STOP and it’s time for me to listen," wrote Vonn, photographed in Santa Monica, Calif., in July 2018. "Honestly, retiring isn’t what upsets me. Retiring without reaching my goal is what will stay with me forever. However, I can look back at 82 World Cup wins, 20 World Cup titles, 3 Olympic medals, 7 World Championship medals and say that I have accomplished something that no other woman in HISTORY has ever done, and that is something that I will be proud of FOREVER!" Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @kendrickbrinson for TIME

@staceyabrams will deliver the Democratic response to President Trump’s State of the Union address next week, Senate Minority Leader @chuckschumer told reporters on Jan. 29. Schumer said he asked Abrams—photographed in #Atlanta on Election Night in November 2018—three weeks ago and “was very delighted when she agreed.” Abrams narrowly lost the governor's race in #Georgia against Republican Brian Kemp after a challenge over blocked votes, the Associated Press reports. “She is just a great spokesperson. She is an incredible leader. She has led the charge for voting rights, which is at the root of just about everything else,” Schumer said. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @gdemczuk for TIME

A man salvages an image of Jesus Christ from a building that was destroyed after a rare and powerful tornado stuck Havana, Cuba, on Jan. 28. At least three people were killed and more than 172 were injured, the Associated Press reports. The Cuban Center for Meteorology labeled the tornado a Category F3, with winds between 155 and 199 miles per hour, the AP adds. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @yamillageacosta—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

A yellow legal pad with the words "5,000 troops to Colombia" was held by John Bolton, the U.S. national security adviser, at a White House news conference on #Venezuela on Jan. 28. There was no mention of troops in Colombia during Monday's announcement that the U.S. was imposing sanctions on Venezuela’s state-owned oil company, a move that came after President Trump recognized opposition lawmaker @jguaido as Venezuela's president over Nicolás Maduro last week. The embattled leader remains in power despite diplomatic and economic pressure by the U.S. and allies to press for regime change. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

Firefighters search for bodies in the region of Córrego do Feijão in Brumadinho, southeastern #Brazil, on Jan. 27, two days after the collapse of a dam at an iron-ore mine belonging to the country's giant mining company Vale. A barrier at the site burst on Friday, the Associated Press reports, spewing millions of tons of reddish-brown mud that engulfed roads, vehicles and buildings. At least 60 people were killed, authorities said, and hopes are fading for an estimate 300 others who remain missing. Photograph by @douglasmagno—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

The village of Tuntou in Hebei province proclaims itself the lantern capital of #China, producing millions of the red decorations associated with the country’s biggest holiday of the year. In Chinese culture, red is meant to bring luck and #happiness, and the fabric of each lantern is adorned with characters wishing for health, peace and prosperity. In Tuntou, where @kevinfrayer photographed workers at a local factory on Jan. 24, most of the production is at small, family-owned factories that supply markets across China, Asia and across the world. The Lunar New Year falls on Feb. 5, and marks the beginning of the Year of the Pig. Photograph by @kevinfrayer—@gettyimages

These photographs look like they might come from any typical business meeting. Instead, the series “Bilateral Rooms” by Ukraine-based photographer @mpalinchakphoto reveals the everyday spaces where some of the world’s most powerful figures come together to make crucial decisions that shape the lives of millions of people. Palinchak opens the closed doors to the negotiation rooms where the action takes place: from NATO summits to the United Nations General Assembly and even to this year’s World Economic Forum in #Davos. Each room offers up something similar: minimalist interiors, nondescript furniture and subdued colors. See more pictures at the link in bio. Photographs by @mpalinchakphoto

@chipotle was once the envy of entrepreneurs everywhere. Founded in 1993, the #burrito empire's formula embraced the best of fast #food (low prices, quick service, big portions) while positioning itself as the industry’s antithesis, with fresh ingredients and a corporate ethos that emphasized integrity and #sustainability. At the peak of 2015, 1.5 million people ate at #Chipotle every day. Then came the meltdown. In August 2015, customers were sickened by norovirus in California and salmonella in Minnesota. That was followed by an E. coli outbreak linked to locations in Washington State and Oregon, and then another norovirus incident in Boston. In total, about 500 people reported getting sick, and the string of food-safety issues sent the company’s stock plummeting from a high of more than $750 to under $400. Sales slumped by nearly one-third. Federal consumer-protection watchdogs launched an investigation. (The case is ongoing.) CEO Brian Niccol, who had been running @tacobell, took over in March 2018 to execute a turnaround. “The things that make us unique, we’re quadrupling down on that,” says Niccol, photographed while lunching near Chipotle’s new headquarters in Newport Beach. A new management team is also in the midst of experiments designed to lure consumers new and old, from a customer-loyalty program to beefed-up delivery options. He intends to innovate without compromising its simplicity. Niccol’s goal may be no less ambitious than “reshaping food” itself. But first, he has a more basic hurdle to clear: making you love Chipotle again. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @shaughn_and_john for TIME

Zsófia Szamosi prepares backstage ahead of an evening #performance in the play Pali at the Katona József Theater in #Budapest, Hungary, on Jan. 18. The play is produced by PanoDráma, an independent company and a pioneer of verbatim theater in #Hungary. The government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has increasingly turned toward arts and culture to promote a nationalist ideology. #Artists and institutions have come under attack for promoting liberal values. Institutions and cultural producers now fear public funding will only be made available to those in line with the government values. Photograph by @cmcgrath_photo—@gettyimages

The story of how Donald Trump's confidant Roger Stone got to this point—arrested on Jan. 25 and indicted on charges connected to Robert Mueller's Russia investigation—takes place over decades, not months. Stone’s history with @realdonaldtrump is a long one, and his #Trump boosterism was in keeping with a political career going back nearly half a century. Though Stone had volunteered for the 1964 Barry Goldwater campaign, it was the reelection campaign of Richard #Nixon—whose face is tattooed on his back—that launched his career. He would later acknowledge his part in the Nixon campaign's “dirty tricks” and wasn't shy about his admiration for him after Watergate, saying in 2017 it "has to do with his resilience." He called the #tattoo—shown to @markpetersonpixs in New York the following year—"a daily reminder that in life, when you get knocked down, when things don’t go your way, when you’re defeated, you got to get up and fight again.” Read more about how Stone connects Trump to Nixon at the link in bio. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs—@reduxpictures

It was the first battle in the war between @realdonaldtrump and the newly empowered @speakerpelosi. At stake were the fate of #immigration reform, border security and government spending during the #Trump presidency, and political clout with both the Republican and Democratic grassroots. And there was no doubt who won and who lost. Speaking from the Rose Garden on Jan. 25, Trump retreated from his demand for $5.7 billion for a border wall to reopen the government, endorsing a three-week stopgap measure that would immediately end the shutdown without any additional border security funding. The retreat could have ripple effects far beyond the argument over a wall, setting a template for future face-offs on everything from executive privilege to health care, immigration and infrastructure. Trump used every tactic he knows: a last-minute veto threat, aggressive tweets, a prime-time address from the Oval Office, a visit to the border, walking out of a high-stakes negotiation, and it didn’t work. “We have reached a deal to end the shutdown and reopen the federal government,” he said. “After 36 days of spirited debate and dialogue, I have seen and heard from enough Democrats and Republicans that they are willing to put partisanship aside—I think—and put the security of the American people first.” In this photograph, Trump returns to the Oval Office after his remarks. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

"The disappearance of a warrior." Two days after a plane carrying Argentine forward @emilianosala9 vanished during a flight from Nantes in western France to Cardiff in Wales, flowers and candles are left with the front page of French #sports newspaper @lequipe in front of the entrance of an @fcnantes training center in La Chapelle-sur-Erdre on Jan. 23. Sala was on his way to the Welsh capital to train with his new teammates for the first time after completing a £15 million ($19 million) move to @cardiffcityfc. Authorities called off the operation to locate Sala and the pilot after neither were found during a three-day search near the Channel Islands. Photograph by @loicvenance—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Leonardo Mayer of Argentina plays a shot with @joaosousaoficial of Portugal during their Men's Doubles semifinal match against @johnwpeers of Australia and @henrikontinen of Finland during Day 11 of the #AustralianOpen in Melbourne on Jan. 24. Peers and Kontinen advanced to the final, set for Jan. 26. On Friday, the Associated Press reports, Australia’s second-largest city is projected to experience its hottest day in a decade. Photograph by @scottbarbourphotographer—@gettyimages #🎾

Who should qualify for #asylum? To whom should #Americans grant refuge? There are no easy policy answers to these questions. What’s clear, however, is that two years into Donald #Trump’s presidency, his black-and-white approach to #immigration is having a measurable effect. By June 2018, fewer than 15% of people applying for asylum were allowed to proceed through the process, down from nearly 33% a year earlier. Carlos Guerra, 62, traveled with a migrant caravan from his home in Copán, Honduras. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

Darileni Rodríguez, 25, and her husband Francisco Soto, 23, along with children in tow, were among thousands of #families who had gathered in late November in encampments outside #Tijuana. They represent a tiny fraction of the record-breaking 258 million international #migrants, defined by the U.N. as people living outside their country of birth. Taken one at a time, each is an individual, a mixture of strengths and weaknesses, hope and despair. But collectively, they represent something greater than the sum of their parts. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

Darileni Rodríguez, 25, and her husband Francisco Soto, 23, left their home in #Honduras to join the #migrant caravan with three #children in tow: Frederick Rodríguez, 2; Sharon Pérez Rodríguez, 3 (twin on left); and Rous Pérez Rodríguez, 3 (twin on right). They fled Honduras because they didn’t have enough food. “Sometimes you go one day, two days, without eating,” she told @time. “I can take it, but the children can’t.” Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

Taken one at a time, each migrant is an individual, a mixture of strengths and weaknesses, hope and despair. But collectively, they represent something greater than the sum of their parts. The forces that pushed them from their homes have combined with a series of global factors that pulled them abroad: the long peace that followed the Cold War in the developed world, the accompanying expansion of international travel, liberalized policies for #refugees and the relative wealth of developed countries, especially in Europe and the U.S., the No. 1 destination for #migrants. The force is tidal and has not been reversed by walls, by separating children from their parents or by deploying troops. Were the world’s total population of international migrants in 2018 gathered from the places where they have sought new lives and placed under one flag, they would be its fifth largest country. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

Merlin Alfaro, 31, and her children, José Luis Guevara, 3, and Maydelin Guevara, 7, traveled from their home in #Honduras to Tijuana, #Mexico, at the southern U.S. border with a #migrant caravan in late 2018. All told, more than 159,000 migrants filed for #asylum in the U.S. in fiscal year 2018, a 274% increase over 2008. Meanwhile, the total number of apprehensions along the southern border has decreased substantially—nearly 70% since fiscal year 2000. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global #migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

“People are starting to say that they hate refugees,” says Eman Albadawi, an English #teacher from Aleppo, #Syria. She fled her country in 2015 after some of her students began disappearing and others showed up with injuries from bombings nearby. She now lives with her three young children in Anröchte, #Germany, where anti-immigrant policies are on the rise. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

Months of reporting by @time correspondents around the world reveal a stubborn reality: we are living in a global society increasingly roiled by challenges that can be neither defined nor contained by physical barriers. That goes for climate change, terrorism, pandemics, nascent technologies and cyber-attacks. It also applies to one of the most significant global developments of the past quarter-century: the unprecedented explosion of global migration. Angel Arrecis Luna, 33, who traveled with the #migrant caravan from #Guatemala to #Tijuana, Mexico, last year, is among the record-breaking 258 million international migrants, defined by the U.N. as people living outside their country of birth. The total number has more than doubled since 1985 and ballooned by 36 million since 2010. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

For this week’s cover story, @time turned to @davidemonteleonestudio to create a series of powerful black and white #portraits that humanize the larger story of global #migration. Inspiration came from his personal project “In the Russian East,” which was influenced by Richard #Avedon’s renowned series “In the American West.” Both photographers were inventive in how they framed their subjects—allowing the individuals or #families to literally carry over across the borders of the image. “The choice was appropriate to recall what America is built on: a large number of working migrants from all over the world,” Monteleone told @time. “This is equally true nowadays in Europe.” Monteleone and a small multimedia team traveled to #Tijuana in late November 2018, as a large #migrant caravan arrived at the U.S.-Mexico border. He taped a white vinyl backdrop on a wall outside a camp, and in between rain showers he interviewed and photographed dozens of migrants. “Eliminating the desperate conditions in which migrants are generally depicted allows the viewer to reflect on the story of the individual rather than the stereotypical ideas surrounding the migratory experience,” he said. Monteleone also traveled to Germany to photograph migrants who fled the civil war in Syria and to Murfreesboro, Tenn. There, he photographed Albertina and her daughter, Yaquelin, seen here, as they wait to hear if they will be granted #asylum in the U.S. Read @time's full special report, on why the forces of global migration can’t be stopped, at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidemonteleonestudio for TIME

People raise their hands during a massive anti-government rally against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro in #Caracas on Jan. 23. Juan Guaido (@jguaido), head of the opposition-controlled congress, declared himself the country's "acting president" in a defiant speech on Wednesday, a move that was quickly recognized by @realdonaldtrump's administration and other nations including Canada, Brazil and Colombia. #Maduro responded by cutting off diplomatic relations with the U.S. and announced that #American diplomats had 72 hours to leave #Venezuela. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @federicoparra—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Government workers, contractors and others affected by the partial shutdown show their displeasure during a #protest in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 23. Holding paper plates bearing slogans like "General Strike 2019" and "Jobs Not Walls," they filled the Hart Senate Office Building’s main atrium. News headlines throughout focused on a new poll showing a majority of #Americans blame President @realdonaldtrump for the record-long shutdown and the battle over where his State of the Union address, if it happens, will be delivered. "I look forward to seeing you on the evening of January 29 in the chamber of the House of Representatives,” Trump wrote in a letter to @speakerpelosi. “It would be very sad for our our country if the State of the Union was not delivered on time, on schedule, and very importantly, on location!” Pelosi responded less than three hours later, telling #Trump she would not authorize the speech in the House chamber, even though she had unofficially invited him earlier in the month, until the government is reopened. On Friday, about 800,000 federal workers are scheduled to miss another #paycheck. Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

Paul Whelan, the former U.S. Marine accused by #Russia of being a spy, speaks to his lawyers from the defendant’s cage during a pretrial hearing in #Moscow on Jan. 22. His court-appointed lawyer has acknowledged that Whelan was carrying “information constituting state secrets” on a flash drive when arrested in December, but said Whelan hadn’t opened the drive, which he thought held travel photos. Whelan, who maintains he is innocent of an unspecified “act of espionage,” faces up to 20 years in prison. Photograph by Mladen Antonov—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Colleagues and relatives of six staff members who were killed in last week's attack on a luxury hotel complex in #Nairobi hold their portraits during a memorial service at the Consolata Shrine on Jan. 23. At least 21 people were killed in the terrorist attack claimed by Somali extremist group al-Shabab on Jan. 15, which ended after an almost 20-hour siege in which hundreds of civilians were rescued, and the five attackers killed. Photograph by Yasuyoshi Chiba—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Educators, #parents, students and supporters of the Los Angeles #teachers strike wave and cheer in Grand Park in downtown Los Angeles on Jan. 22. A tentative deal was reached on Tuesday between school officials and the teachers union that would allow educators to return to #classrooms, the Associated Press reports, after a six-day strike against #America’s second-largest district. “I’m proud to announce that, pending approval by the teachers represented by [United Teachers Los Angeles] and educational professionals and this Board of Education, we have an agreement that will allow our teachers to go back to work on the campuses tomorrow,” @mayorofla Eric Garcetti announced, accompanied by leaders of the Los Angeles Unified School District and the union. The agreement was broadly described as including a 6% pay increase, the AP adds, and a commitment to reduce class sizes over four years. Read more on TIME.com. Photograph by @scottheins—@gettyimages

The daughter of a former political aide had no idea she had a piece of #history sitting in a drawer. In May 1964, less than a year after making his “I have a dream” speech, Martin Luther King Jr. (#MLK) delivered remarks at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum that highlighted the need for justice and called for an end to segregation, as Senators in Washington, D.C., debated the Civil Rights Act. “Now is the time to make real the promises of #democracy,” King said. “Now is the time to open the floodgates of opportunity and allow now an avalanche of justice to pour upon us. Now is the time to get rid of #segregation and discrimination. Now is the time to make justice a reality for all of God’s children. This is the challenge of the hour.” Barbara Moss’s father, Jay A. Brown, worked as an assistant to Democratic Rep. Thomas Rees and attended the event, capturing it in color film. “What me and my mother can figure is that my father probably took his camera with him this day—he always had his camera—and by some miracle popped in color film into the camera,” Moss tells TIME. Describing him as a "purger," she was surprised to find these pictures. “These are an American treasure, they shouldn’t be in a drawer,” she said. “If Martin Luther King were alive today, what would he be saying now?” she wondered. “His message was so important and resonates today clearly.” Read the full story, and see more pictures, at the link in bio. Photograph by Jay A. Brown, courtesy of the Brown family

Windie Jo Lazenko, 50, is a social worker and survivor of sex trafficking who has spent the past decade campaigning against sexual exploitation and advocating for victims across the United States. Lazenko started working with anti-trafficking organizations in 2007, learning on the job how to minister to victims and campaign for awareness. In 2012 she was working for a support organization for sex-trafficking survivors in Florida when she started hearing strippers and sex workers talking about the money to be made in the Bakken oil fields of North Dakota and Montana. Figuring that wherever there was a demand for prostitutes, pimps and traffickers were sure to follow, Lazenko drove to #Williston on a reconnaissance mission. The situation, she says, was “worse than horrific.” Pimps had colonized the two local strip clubs and most of the hotels, but bartenders and front-desk managers had no idea what was going on. The only women’s shelter in town was for domestic-abuse victims, and it wasn’t equipped to deal with trafficking victims. Police investigators, Lazenko says, often ended up alienating and retraumatizing victims with insensitive questions about the number of johns they had slept with or why they never tried to get away. Today Lazenko spends most of her time on the road, traveling between conferences and conducting training sessions for cops and social-service organizations. She has testified before state lawmakers and served as an expert witness in sex-trafficking cases in Florida, Arizona, Montana and North Dakota. “We have to keep talking about sex trafficking,” she says, “otherwise it will stay a hidden epidemic.” Read @arynebaker’s full story at the link in bio. Photographs by @lynseyaddario for TIME

For the uninitiated, Jane the Virgin is loosely based on a Venezuelan telenovela about a virgin who is accidentally artificially inseminated. Jane decides to keep the baby, a choice complicated by the fact that her longtime boyfriend is planning to propose. Meanwhile, the unintentional donor turns out to be an old crush. She navigates the love triangle with the help of her mother and grandmother, a trinity of kind, powerful and complicated women. To call the show a “guilty pleasure” would be to minimize its genius, writes TIME's Eliana Dockterman: the series proved that a warmhearted #heroine could be as complex and enthralling as the difficult men, like Mad Men’s Don Draper, who dominated prestige #television when Jane premiered. Behind the scenes as well, the show stood out from the rest of #Hollywood. Showrunner Jennie Urman has a team of 10 #women and three men for her writing staff. Four writers are Latinx, and women direct half the episodes. It was because of Urman that Gina Rodriguez (@hereisgina) fulfilled her own dream to direct, after others had rebuffed her: “People were just like, ‘You’re just a little Latina actress. How are you going to be a director?'” Though movements like Time’s Up (of which Rodriguez is an active member) are dedicated to addressing sexism and racism in Hollywood, #Latina women still account for a mere 7% of all speaking roles in major films. Just one Latina director, Patricia Riggen, helmed one of the 1,200 top-grossing #movies from 2007 to 2018, according to a recent study. Rodriguez says she is an activist first. On every project, she has demanded inclusion on a par with @cwjanethevirgin’s. “I refuse to enter a space where it’s not as liberating as this. Are 50% of the writers women? The directors? Are those women intersectional?” she says, referring to representation across race, class, sexual orientation and other aspects of a person’s identity. “No? O.K., let’s change that or find yourself someone else.” Read more at the link in bio. Photograph by Rozette Rago (@hellorozette) for TIME

The body of Abdalla Mohamed Dahir is buried in #Nairobi on Jan. 16. Dahir and a colleague were among those slain after al-Shabab militants stormed a luxury hotel complex in a brazen attack on #Kenya's capital a day earlier. The death toll climbed to 21 on Wednesday, not including five militants who were killed, the Associated Press reports. Photograph by @andrewrenneisen—@gettyimages

Anyone who ever met Carol Channing, writes @theharveyfierstein, the Tony Award–winning #actor and playwright, will tell you that there was no greater thrill than to walk into a room and find her there. Those giant saucer eyes, whether bedecked in black daisy lashes or, as in later years, peering out at you from behind mammoth eyeglass frames, were alit with humor and intelligence, endless curiosity and welcome. There was no smile on this planet that engendered more joy than hers. Her marionette arms embraced you with a love that sent electric shocks straight to your soul—and her voice, that unmistakable trumpeting growl, invited imitation by even the least talented mimic, because you just had to know what it felt like to sound that way. #CarolChanning, who died Jan. 15 at 97, was so much more than an actress or a #performer or even a star. She was an icon, a true #legend, completely original, absolutely singular, recognizable a mile away all around the globe. Channing, photographed in 1967, will always be remembered for her stage persona in 'Hello, Dolly!' and film performances in movies like 'Thoroughly Modern Millie,' but it didn’t matter what material she was performing. Classic role or cheesy #TV special, all you cared about was spending as much time as you could in the glow of that magical firelight that was Carol Channing. Photograph by Photoshot/Hulton Archive/@gettyimages

The #British government suffered its biggest defeat in modern parliamentary history on Jan. 15, after lawmakers rejected Prime Minister Theresa May’s flagship #Brexit deal by a margin of 230 votes. The deal was intended to smooth #Britain’s departure from the E.U. by setting out the terms of their post-split relationship. Unless an alternative plan can win the backing of Parliament, the country is on a default path to crash out of the bloc on March 29. That’s if Brexit isn’t delayed or canceled. In June 2016, 52% of British voters opted to leave the E.U.—but May warned in a last-ditch speech that if lawmakers rejected her deal, they would run “the risk of no Brexit at all.” That outcome is technically still possible, but unlikely. After all, on Jan. 16, May narrowly survived a vote of no confidence that could have toppled her government. In this photograph, May leaves the lectern after delivering remarks outside her 10 Downing St. residence in London, during which she said her door remains open to talks with Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn. It was another reminder of the extent to which Brexit has upended British #politics: many of the same lawmakers who dealt May the largest landslide loss in living memory voted to keep her on as Prime Minister just 24 hours later. The historic defeat nevertheless means May will have to compromise. Read more on TIME.com. Photograph by @oliscarff—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Striking teachers march in #LosAngeles on Jan. 14 to demand better school funding, smaller class sizes and higher pay. The city is home to the second largest #school district in the U.S., with some 500,000 #students. Tens of thousands of #teachers took to the streets, joining an ongoing national movement spurred by a lack of #education funding. The school strike, which took place after negotiations for a 6.5% pay raise broke down, was the first Los Angeles had seen in 30 years. Photograph by @alexwelshphoto

@rafaelnadal of #Spain during his second-round match against Matthew Ebden of Australia during Day 3 of the #AustralianOpen in Melbourne on Jan. 16. Nadal beat Ebden 6-3, 6-2, 6-2 to move into the third round. Photograph by @scottbarbourphotographer—@gettyimages #🎾

@naomiosakatennis eased into the second round of the Australian Open in #Melbourne on Jan. 15. The 21-year-old who stunned @serenawilliams at the U.S. Open last year beat Magda Linette of Poland 6-4, 6-2. The great players have a way of finding another gear in the Grand Slam spotlight, writes @time's Sean Gregory. Osaka has shown that she has the power game to beat the best. But can she do it when everyone is expecting her to—and millions of dollars are riding on it? The end of the Williams era may not be here, but it is in sight. Osaka is wary of any “next Serena” label. She’s quieter than her idol, and she owns just one Grand Slam trophy to date. But she knows that it’s there for the taking. “You really never know what people can do,” Osaka says. “And how people can change. I don’t think there is ever going to be another Serena Williams. I think I’m going to be me. And I hope people are O.K. with that.” Photograph by @caitoppermann for TIME

With a measured tone and carefully worded answers, William Barr sought on Jan. 15 to reassure senators that he would protect the Justice Department’s vaunted independence if he were confirmed as Attorney General. Over the years, Barr said he’s told friends who’ve mused about becoming the nation’s top cop that they shouldn’t do it if they want to have a future in #politics, since at any point they may need to take an unpopular stand. But as a former attorney general who served under President George H.W. Bush, and as a private lawyer in the twilight of his career, he argued that he can take on the powerful role. “I feel like I’m in a position in life where I can do the right thing and not really care about the consequences,” Barr, 68, told the Senate Judiciary Committee in #Washington, D.C. “I am not going to be bullied into doing anything I think is wrong.” Read more about how Barr, who was nominated by President #Trump, tried to reassure #Democrats at his confirmation hearing on TIME.com. Photograph by @davidbutow—@reduxpictures for TIME

Somalia-based extremist group al-Shabab claimed responsibility for a deadly assault in #Kenya's capital on Jan. 15, the Associated Press reports, sending people fleeing in panic as explosions and heavy gunfire reverberated through #Nairobi’s Westlands neighborhood. The hotel complex that came under attack is less than two kilometers from Westgate Mall, where the group’s militants killed dozens of people in a 2013 siege, and is in what is considered one of the most secure areas of the city. James Gambill, 2, of Cartersville, Ga., navigates his way through #Georgia lawmakers as he waits for his father, Republican Rep. Matthew Gambill, to be sworn in during the first session at the State Capitol building in #Atlanta on Jan. 14. Photograph by @alyssapointerphoto—@ajcnews/@apnews

A #protester flashes the victory gesture as he stands next to burning tires while blocking a road during a demonstration against corruption and lack of services in the southern city of Basra, #Iraq, on Jan. 11. Photograph by Hussein Faleh (@hussein_vii)—@afpphoto/@gettyimages

Many people’s introduction to @naomiosakatennis came in September at the U.S. Open trophy presentation, when the surprise #champion—who stunned @serenawilliams—covered her eyes with her visor as boos rained from the crowd. The moment should have been celebratory—a rising star assuming her place among champions after defeating the greatest of them all. Instead, it was painful. “I didn’t want people to see me crying,” Osaka tells @time, “because that’s pathetic.” At first, Osaka thought the boos were for her. She knew the crowd, and millions more watching on TV, desperately wanted Williams to win a record-tying 24th Grand Slam title after she nearly died after giving birth. Osaka apologized for doing her job and beating her opponent. And so it was that the woman who could be the heir to the Williams sisters met the world through a frowning face and lowered brim. Three months later, she doesn’t fault Williams for fighting with the umpire and upstaging her victory. “Serena is Serena,” Osaka says in her first extended interview since the match. “I didn’t experience her life. I can’t tell her what she’s supposed to do, because there are things that she’s gone through. I have nothing against her or anything. I actually still really love her.” Osaka insists she’s come to terms with it all. She appreciates that Williams did eventually implore the crowd to stop jeering and applaud Osaka with a proper, if belated, ovation. In fact, Osaka insists she wouldn’t change anything about what happened. “In a perfect dream, things would be set exactly the way you would want them,” she says. “But I think it’s more interesting that in real life, things aren’t exactly the way you planned. And there are certain situations that you don’t expect, but they come to you, and I think those situations set up things for further ahead.” Read the full TIME International cover story on TIME.com. Federal offices and museums are shuttered. Trash is piling up in national parks. Airport-security personnel are working without pay. Recipients of housing aid are wondering if they’ll soon be evicted. This is #America during a partial government shutdown, now in its third week. But step back from the sordid details, writes @time's Molly Ball, and you could hardly get a more accurate tableau of America’s new political reality: a nonfunctioning federal government whose leaders, each insisting the stakes are too high to budge, have retreated to their corners. At the center of the drama are the two towering figures whose clash will define the next biennium: President @realdonaldtrump and emboldened House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (@speakerpelosi), the yang and yin of a divided America, two powerful leaders with their credibility on the line, both convinced they hold the winning hand. Bindu, a 40-year-old law professor, left, and 39-year-old government supplies officer Kanakadurga met just weeks ago. Now they finish each other’s sentences. The pair, who entered the Lord Ayyappa temple in Sabarimala, southern Kerala, on Jan. 2, became the first #women to officially do so since the Supreme Court overturned a longstanding ban in September that prevented women of “menstruating age”—defined as between the ages of 10 and 50—from entering the temple complex. Afterward, the head priest shut the doors for an hour-long “purification ceremony.” Across #Kerala, in southern #India, mobs claiming to be offended devotees are going on a rampage, damaging buses, burning effigies and throwing stones and crude bombs in the streets. One man has died, and hundreds have been injured. Police have arrested more than 5,700 people. Many #Hindus believe that the energy, or chaitanya, of a woman’s body is polluted during menstruation. Most temples allow women to enter as long as they are not on their period, but the #Sabarimala temple is one of the few banning women of childbearing age altogether. “People will always spit at those trying to push for social change,” Kanakadurga says. “We’ll be asked what’s the hurry to become #equal, why us two, why today, why not tomorrow, or why this way. It’s part of any transition. I just appeal to my brothers on the streets to find some #tolerance within them, and stop the violence in our name.” Read more on TIME.com. Just off the soaring, tourist-filled rotunda of the U.S. Capitol building, down a chandeliered hallway, up a few floors in what feels like the world’s tiniest elevator, in a narrow, echoing corridor, lies the hideaway of @sensusancollins. The private office, a perk doled out by seniority, is appointed in creams and florals and feels warm but not exactly homey. Most of all, it is secluded—no staff, no uninvited visitors, no constituents. And it was in this hidden space in late September that the Republican from Maine weighed one of the most divisive decisions of her 21-year career in #Congress: whether to vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh, a conservative judge accused of sexual assault, to the Supreme Court. Collins faced an onslaught of pressure from the left to oppose the nomination. None of it daunted Collins, who has spent decades as a pivotal swing vote in the #Senate. Recalling the episode in November, Collins says she was “baffled” that #activists thought they could threaten her into voting their way. “I would never be intimidated by that,” she says. In the end, Collins cast one of the decisive votes for Kavanaugh, announcing her decision with a speech that shredded any illusions that she was unsure about her choice. Her vigorous defense of Kavanaugh, coming from one of the Senate’s last remaining moderates, showed just how polarized the chamber has become in the #Trump era. And it highlighted how difficult it is to be a centrist when everyone else has retreated to hyperpartisan corners. In this moment in American #politics, Collins can seem like the last of her kind. When Aya, a 23-year-old Syrian #refugee living in the west #German town of Xanten, came home from her language lessons one afternoon in October, the house was in disarray. A frantic search revealed that her 2-year-old son’s stroller was missing, along with their passports and IDs. She tried her #husband; his phone was off. A few hours later Aya received a telephone call from #Syria. “Go pack your bags,” her husband’s brother told her. “Mohammad is taking Joud to Syria, and he wants you to go with them.” If she wanted to be with her son, she would have to retrace the path she and her husband had taken more than three years ago, when they sought refuge in #Europe. Instead, Aya called the police. Her son, after all, had been born in #Germany. Her time in the country had taught her that she had rights. But it was too late. The police said her husband and son had taken a plane to Greece that morning. Her brother-in-law filled in the rest: as soon as they arrived, a smuggler took them across the border to Turkey, and they were now headed to Syria. A few days later, a series of text messages jolted Aya out of her grief. “If you want your son, you have to come back to us,” her husband wrote from his hometown of Idlib, where a unsteady truce held between the two sides in the #war. “You are becoming German. Come back to your culture, your religion and your people. Come be a good mother again.” In just a few messages, Mohammad laid out a central preoccupation for many Syrian refugees in Germany: how to embrace the freedoms of their new home while preserving the culture and traditions of the one they left behind. In this photograph, Aya sits in the bedroom where Joud once slept. Read more on TIME.com. Photograph by @nannaheitmann for TIME

Bradley Goldman, now 30, began taking #steroids at 18. He’d heard they could interfere with #­fertility—­steroids can shut down the body’s natural production of ­testosterone—but like many young #men, he was more concerned with not having #babies than with having them. Now he and his wife are trying to get pregnant, and though he gave up steroids two years ago, it seems the damage is done. When he got a semen analysis last March, his sperm count came back a flat zero. “It was earth-­shattering,” he says. Infertility is almost always thought of as a woman’s issue, and it’s true that #women bear the greater burden of it. They are the ones who ultimately either get #pregnant or don’t, and regardless of which partner has the fertility problem, the woman’s body is usually the site of treatment. In vitro fertilization, for instance, often requires just a sperm sample from men but a great deal more from their female partners: injections of synthetic hormones, blood tests, ultrasounds. And yet up to 50% of cases in which couples can’t have babies are due in some way to men. More men are talking about it now, but it remains stigmatized, especially in the U.S. Men are largely absent from public conversation around #infertility, and even those who have looked for #support hesitate to identify as someone struggling with male infertility. “I feel like I’m your stereotypical masculine-­looking man,” says Goldman. “I’m tattooed. I have muscles. I work out. And I’m infertile. How many other guys out there that have this machismo, this mind-set about them, are in my shoes as well?” Read TIME's full Special Report, The Future of Babies, on TIME.com.
